title: Khatam Kari (Inlay Work)
technique: Micro-triangle marquetry assembled into star patterns
summary: Delicate Persian marquetry where tiny wood, bone, and metal triangles form intricate geometric surfaces.
facts: High-end boxes, frames, Qur'an stands, furniture.
Each cm² may include hundreds of pieces.

title: Ghalamzani (Metal Engraving)
summary: Engraving and relief-work on metal vessels with floral, arabesque, and epic scenes.

title: Monabbat (Wood Carving)
technique: Relief carving with gouges; arabesque and calligraphy patterns
summary: Expressive Persian wood carving that blends floral arabesques with calligraphic themes.
facts: Oil finish to reveal grain depth.

title: Persian Carpet (Farsh)
technique: Asymmetric (Persian) knot; complex medallion & boteh motifs
summary: World-renowned carpets with refined knotting, rich palettes, and symbolic motifs.
facts: Knot density from 120 to 1000+ KPSI in silk pieces.

title: Kilim (Gelim)
technique: Flatweave tapestry; slit and interlocking weaves
summary: Flatwoven rugs with bold tribal geometry and portable utility.

title: Termeh (Luxury Brocade)
summary: Opulent brocade textiles famed for lustrous boteh patterns and ceremonial use.
facts: Used in tablecloths and ceremonial garments.

title: Kashi Haft-Rang (Seven-Color Tiles)
technique: Firing pre-painted tiles with seven signature colors
summary: Iconic multi-color tiles used on mosques and palaces; efficient for large murals.
facts: Colors: cobalt, turquoise, white, black, yellow, red, green.

title: Lajvardina Pottery
technique: Cobalt ground with overglaze luster painting
summary: Deep blue ground with shimmering golden motifs — rare and museum-grade.

title: Minaei (Enamel-painted Tiles)
summary: Narrative tiles with figures and calligraphy; a jewel of Persian walls.
facts: Historic panels survive in museum collections.

title: Minakari (Enamel on Metal)
technique: Multiple-fire enamel layers on metal vessels
summary: Radiant enamel art with floral panels on bowls, plates, and jewelry.
facts: Color depth achieved by sequential firings.

title: Firouzeh Koobi (Turquoise Inlay)
technique: Setting tiny turquoise chips into mastic on metal surfaces
summary: Glittering turquoise mosaic on vases, plates, and jewelry with Persian blue aura.
facts: Uses off-cut turquoise stones from Neyshabur mines.
Polished to achieve continuous gemstone sheen.

title: Silverwork (Tabriz School)
summary: Intricate silver vessels and jewelry distinguished by clean chase lines.
facts: High purity silver for bright tone.
